abstract: Continental was already the dominant player at Newark Liberty International Airport. But in merging with United, it gains a much bigger network of domestic routes and connections to the rest of the world that would leave its rivals in New York — Delta Air Lines and American Airlines — struggling to catch up.
snippet: Continental was already the dominant player at Newark Liberty International Airport. But in merging with United, it gains a much bigger network of domestic routes and connections to the rest of the world that would leave its rivals in New York — D...
lead_paragraph: The combination of United and Continental Airlines would upend the balance of power at New York’s airports, Jad Mouawad and Patrick McGeehan report in The New York Times.

headline.main: Rumblings in the New York Skies

abstract: Executives testified that they did all they could to keep Bear Stearns afloat before it fell victim to an unstoppable run on the bank.
snippet: Executives testified that they did all they could to keep Bear Stearns afloat before it fell victim to an unstoppable run on the bank.
lead_paragraph: Members of a panel investigating the financial crisis on Wednesday challenged former Bear Stearns executives on their view of what caused the Wall Street firm to implode two years ago, The Associated Press reports.

headline.main: Executives Questioned on Demise of Bear Stearns

abstract: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has released documents that show Bear Stearns appeared optimistic about its prospects a year before the rapidly growing subprime mortgage crisis caused the firm’s demise in March 2008.
snippet: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has released documents that show Bear Stearns appeared optimistic about its prospects a year before the rapidly growing subprime mortgage crisis caused the firm’s demise in March 2008.
lead_paragraph: The Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission has released documents that show Bear Stearns appeared optimistic about its prospects a year before the rapidly growing subprime mortgage crisis caused the firm’s demise in March 2008.

headline.main: A Look at Bear Stearns Before Its Downfall

abstract: The former heads of Bear Stearns disagreed Wednesday over how much the firm’s huge reliance on borrowed money contributed to its demise.
snippet: The former heads of Bear Stearns disagreed Wednesday over how much the firm’s huge reliance on borrowed money contributed to its demise.
lead_paragraph: The former heads of Bear Stearns disagreed Wednesday afternoon over how much the firm’s huge reliance on borrowed money contributed to its demise, with James E. Cayne arguing that the firm was overleveraged, while Alan Schwartz, his successor as chief executive, arguing that the firm was adequately capitalized.

headline.main: Cayne and Schwartz at Odds Over Bear’s Leverage

abstract: Mitch Jacobs, founder and chief executive of On Deck Capital, talks about what he hopes will be a revolutionary new approach to getting credit to small businesses.
snippet: Mitch Jacobs, founder and chief executive of On Deck Capital, talks about what he hopes will be a revolutionary new approach to getting credit to small businesses.
lead_paragraph: In a small-business conversation we’ve just published, Mitch Jacobs, founder and chief executive of On Deck Capital, talks about what he hopes will be a revolutionary new  approach to getting credit to small businesses. Among those who believe in the approach are James D. Robinson III, former chairman and chief executive of American Express, and Alan Blinder, an economist and former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, both of whom serve on On Deck’s board.

headline.main: Is This the Way to Get Credit to Small Businesses?

abstract: The former bosses of Bear Stearns said Wednesday afternoon that they did not believe their firm was too big to fail or too big.
snippet: The former bosses of Bear Stearns said Wednesday afternoon that they did not believe their firm was too big to fail or too big.
lead_paragraph: The former bosses of Bear Stearns said Wednesday afternoon that they did not believe their firm was too big to fail or too big to manage and that they were “shocked” when it suddenly collapsed in March 2008.
